stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream designing the new "inside-the-pyramid" sub-area for Course 14 (paper-craft world).  He also demos a finished, very difficult “saw” sub-area for Course 15 and chats about overall progress and polish.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is almost finished – only the pyramid interior and one other sub-area remain before the whole course is complete.
development_findings.quote: There’s only two areas missing in the papercraft level and then Course 14 is complete.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 now contains a finished “saw” room that Kaze considers the hardest section in the game so far; Zeina struggled to beat it, which is being used as a difficulty benchmark.
development_findings.quote: It is by far the most difficult area in the game and when Zeina played it she had trouble beating it, but I think the difficulty is fine considering it’s Course 15.

development_findings.summary: Primary design goal for the pyramid: feel like an overwhelming cave maze at first, then ‘click’ so players can navigate confidently.
development_findings.quote: I want there to be a moment of the player going ‘Ah, this is how it works,’ and from then on it’s not a maze anymore.

development_findings.summary: Abandoned ideas: full color-coded paths and persistent footsteps were rejected due to N64 memory / programming overhead.
development_findings.quote: Making that would be absolute torture… the technical limitations are existent.

development_findings.summary: Chosen layout: one long main path with eight shortcut branches, each hiding a red coin; players who grasp the pattern can back-track along the main route efficiently.
development_findings.quote: You might not immediately realize it’s just one long path with a bunch of sidetracks, but once you do you can just do the red-coin mission like that.

development_findings.summary: One-way sections and height landmarks (e.g., a large central cliff where multiple entrances are visible) will prevent the simple ‘follow the left wall’ solution.
development_findings.quote: I want some one-ways in there so you can’t just do the follow-left-wall strategy because it ruins every maze instantly.

development_findings.summary: A new BLJ exploit appeared during testing; Kaze flagged it as a critical bug to fix.
development_findings.quote: Apparently you can BLJ here. Oh my god – interesting. That’s a very important bug to fix.

development_findings.summary: Render-mode error turned geometry into wireframe; cause traced to incorrect alpha settings.
development_findings.quote: This is definitely from a render mode not being set correctly – turns everything into wireframe somehow.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values ‘confusion that resolves’ over traditional logic puzzles and dislikes mechanics that feel forced.
context_findings.quote: The difference is there’s no active effort required from the player; you just do the thing and suddenly understand it.

context_findings.summary: He is transparent about income: roughly $10k a year from YouTube, monthly living costs around $2.8k for his family.
context_findings.quote: Look, my analytics – $900 this month, in a year it’s like $10,000.

context_findings.summary: Shows pragmatic view on finances and possible legal risk: jokes about opening an OnlyFans if Nintendo sues.
context_findings.quote: If Nintendo ever completely sues me, maybe I need to start an OnlyFans. Maybe that’s the play.

context_findings.summary: Expresses consistent worry about difficulty spikes and player accessibility, using Zeina’s play-tests as a gauge.
context_findings.quote: I had Zeina trying to play it and she didn’t really have a shot at beating it, so that’s why I feel like it’s a little difficult.

biobak.summary: Joins chat, offers feedback on social-media post timing and suggests alternative texture approach (cardboard with stapled paper instead of Styrofoam).
biobak.quote: Posting times are pretty stupid… we should schedule our posts for the next day.

zeina.summary: Play-tested the new saw room and provided difficulty feedback that informed Kaze’s tuning.
zeina.quote: When Zeina played it she had trouble beating it.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Pyramid Maze
key_stories.summary: Kaze began with several heavy-puzzle concepts (color coding, mirrored halves, footstep trails) but deemed them technically impractical.  After live brainstorming, he realized a single main path with shortcut branches meets his ‘confusion then clarity’ goal without overloading the N64.
key_stories.challenge: Design a red-coin sub-area that feels maze-like yet ultimately readable.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed multiple mechanics, evaluated technical cost, rejected those that strained resources, prototyped path layout live.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on main-path-plus-shortcuts structure with one-way segments and a central cliff landmark.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe the idea does just kinda suck… but one main path with a bunch of small paths along it that connect back works.

key_stories.title: Saw Room Difficulty Check
key_stories.summary: Kaze finished a brutal saw-blade platforming room for Course 15. Zeina’s inability to clear it became a reality check; he kept the difficulty but flagged it as the new upper limit.
key_stories.challenge: Ensure late-game challenge without making content impossible.
key_stories.process: Implemented timed saws with rubber-band speed, color-coded assets, observed Zeina’s play-test.
key_stories.outcome: Room retained but noted as ‘hardest so far’; will balance subsequent content accordingly.
key_stories.key_quote: It is by far the most difficult area in the game and when Zeina played it she had trouble beating it.

key_stories.title: Global Coin Counter Debate
key_stories.summary: Chat debated whether 100-coin stars should exist.  Kaze wants a global coin economy; ideas ranged from four-digit HUD to starting levels with existing coins.
key_stories.challenge: Communicate to players that coins persist across levels, abolishing the 100-coin star.
key_stories.process: Considered UI changes (0100 display), overworld coin gates, and coin carry-over examples.
key_stories.outcome: No final decision; leaning toward having players begin Course 1 with pre-collected coins as implicit tutorial.
key_stories.key_quote: Just starting the level with some amount of coins is going to be enough to know that there’s no 100 coins there.
